Below is a self‐contained ARC‐style puzzle, along with an “analogy” (the underlying logic of the transformation), and a sample solution program written in Michael Hodel’s DSL. The puzzle is small‐scale (maximum 10×10), with three training pairs and one test pair. 

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
1) ARC‐Like Task (JSON Format)
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

{
  "train": [
    {
      "input": [
        [0, 7],
        [9, 9],
        [9, 7]
      ],
      "output": [
        [9, 7],
        [9, 9],
        [0, 7]
      ]
    },
    {
      "input": [
        [1, 1, 9],
        [2, 0, 2]
      ],
      "output": [
        [9, 1, 1],
        [2, 0, 2]
      ]
    },
    {
      "input": [
        [0, 0, 9, 9],
        [1, 1, 9, 9],
        [7, 7, 7, 7],
        [2, 2, 0, 0]
      ],
      "output": [
        [2, 2, 0, 0],
        [7, 7, 7, 7],
        [1, 1, 9, 9],
        [0, 0, 9, 9]
      ]
    }
  ],
  "test": [
    {
      "input": [
        [1, 7],
        [1, 1]
      ],
      "output": [
        [1, 1],
        [1, 7]
      ]
    }
  ]
}

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
2) Analogy (Logic Description)
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
• Compute the grid’s shape, i.e. (height, width).  
• If height ≥ width, mirror the grid horizontally (reverse the row order).  
• Otherwise, mirror the grid vertically (reverse each row from left to right).

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
3) Sample Program in Hodel DSL
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
Below is a possible “solve(grid)” function expressed in the provided DSL. It checks whether the grid’s height and width are equal or if height is greater, then applies hmirror; otherwise it applies vmirror.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
from arc_types import *

def solve(grid: Grid) -> Grid:
    # Extract (h, w) via shape(grid).
    # We want a condition: “(h == w) OR (h > w)” => hmirror; else => vmirror.

    # 1. shape(grid): gives a tuple (h, w).
    hw = shape(grid)  
    # 2. fork(greater, first, last)(hw) means “greater( first(hw), last(hw) )”.
    #    fork(equality, first, last)(hw) means “equality( first(hw), last(hw) )”.
    cond_h_eq_w = fork(equality, first, last)(hw)   # True if h == w
    cond_h_gt_w = fork(greater,  first, last)(hw)   # True if h > w

    # 3. either(...) => logical OR: “cond_h_eq_w OR cond_h_gt_w” 
    #    => True if (h >= w).
    cond_h_ge_w = either(cond_h_eq_w, cond_h_gt_w)

    # 4. branch(condition, ifTrue, ifFalse) => choose hmirror(grid) if true,
    #    else vmirror(grid).
    return branch(cond_h_ge_w, hmirror(grid), vmirror(grid))
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Explanation of the DSL calls (briefly):  
• shape(grid) → (h, w)  
• first(...) and last(...) pick out h and w.  
• greater(..) and equality(..) compare those two values.  
• fork(...) with greater or equality is a concise way of applying “greater(h,w).”  
• either(...) returns True if either sub‐condition is True.  
• branch(...) picks one of hmirror(grid) or vmirror(grid) based on that boolean.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
End of Puzzle  
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
